image.altText: A young man stands with an older woman in front of microphones.

items.synopsis: Billionaire miner Gina Rinehart tried to pressure her son's lawyer into issuing a media statement critical of his attempts to find out about what had happened to his inheritance, the WA Supreme Court is told, which would "throw him under a bus".

title.children: Gina Rinehart tried to get son's lawyer to 'throw him under a bus' over inheritance row, court told

image.altText: Above-ground powerlines string above the treetops against the backdrop of a golden sunset

items.synopsis: WA is facing a potential power shortfall over the coming decade amid the transition to renewables, leading the government to keep the Muja coal-fired power station operating longer than planned.

title.children: Reprieve for coal as potential WA power blackouts forecast amidst renewables transition

image.altText: Cooking on a gas stove

items.synopsis: One of the world's largest green hydrogen projects planned for WA has been shelved, partly due to the state's cheap cost of natural gas.

title.children: Cheap WA gas a factor in cancellation of green hydrogen project, energy company says

image.altText: A young man in a white shirt and black pants walks outside court in Perth next to a man in a grey coat and a reporter's hand.

items.synopsis: Kai Dylan Best will have to spend 20 months behind bars before he can be considered for parole.

title.children: Man, 23, sentenced to more than three years in jail over death of 16-year-old who fell from car

image.altText: Brigid Malone sits at a desk

items.synopsis: Australia's unemployment rate has risen to 3.7 per cent for July, up from 3.5 per cent in June, with 36,000 more people unemployed, according to Australian Bureau of Statistics data.

title.children: Brigid has been looking for a job for months. The latest figures show there are thousands just like her

image.altText: a fire rages over a pig pen

items.synopsis: A probe into a bushfire, which tore through 18,000 hectares of farms and bushland in WA's Wheatbelt region, has led to legal action against Western Power.

title.children: Farmers eye compensation as Western Power charged over devastating Wheatbelt fires

image.altText: A man in a mask sitting on a chair.

items.synopsis: An uprising inspired and led by women was met with a swift crackdown. Now, young dissidents speak to the ABC in a series of interviews conducted in secret.

title.children: 'Friends, it has just started': A hacker in hiding has a message for the world

image.altText: A man wearing a suit and tie stares towards the camera

items.synopsis: Brian Houston insisted he did not go to the police about his father's abuse because he was respecting the wishes of the victim.

title.children: Hillsong founder Brian Houston found not guilty of  concealing his father's sexual abuse of a child

image.altText: Eddie Jones speaks to the media at Sydney Airport.

items.synopsis: Wallabies coach Eddie Jones launches a scathing attack on reporters before his squad fly out of Sydney for the men's Rugby World Cup in France, claiming they are "so bloody negative about everything".

title.children: 'Worst press conference I've ever had': Jones slams media as Wallabies fly out for Rugby World Cup

image.altText: A plane with the LATAM Airlines logo flying

items.synopsis: The LATAM Airlines flight was on its way from Miami to Santiago when its captain fell ill, forcing the other two pilots to proceed with an emergency landing.

title.children: Pilot dies after plane makes emergency landing in Panama

image.altText: a woman looks directly at the camera. She has long brown hair and is wearing a black top.

items.synopsis: Kobie Parfitt feared for her life days before she was killed by her friend Shannon Jeffrey, the Supreme Court in Melbourne heard today. Jeffrey had only been out of prison for less than two weeks when Ms Parfitt was killed.

title.children: Mother of four killed by friend who dumped body down a mineshaft

image.altText: An England player and a Matildas opponent challenge for the ball during the Women's World Cup semifinal.

items.synopsis: The Matildas' 3-1 loss to England creates history by becoming the most-watched TV program since the current audience measurement system began in 2001.

title.children: Matildas' World Cup semifinal sets TV audience record

image.altText: Australia's football superstar Sam Kerr looks sad but gives a thumbs up to the crowd after the Matildas Women's World Cup loss.

items.synopsis: The Matildas call for improved funding for football and urge their plethora of new-found fans to stay on the bandwagon after the Women's World Cup.

title.children: 'Isn't good enough': Sam Kerr, Matildas teammates call for investment, support for football after World Cup run

image.altText: A crocodile sits on a sandy bank while a man fishes nearby

items.synopsis: A viral online video showing a man fishing near a large croc has left authorities dismayed and locals concerned for the future of the well-known reptile.

title.children: Authorities warn against 'life-threatening risks' after man filmed fishing metres from saltwater crocodile

image.altText: Sam Williamson bursts out of the water wearing an Australian gold swimming cap

items.synopsis: Swimming Australia calls a special general meeting to avoid being kicked out of the sport's global governing body due to perceived governance issues.

title.children: Swimming Australia threatened with expulsion from World Aquatics

image.altText: People walk across a street.

items.synopsis: Australia's unemployment rate rose to 3.7 per cent in July, surpassing most economists expectations. It comes as the local sharemarket is trading lower despite a flurry of earnings reports from some of Australia's biggest companies. Follow live.

title.children: Future rate rises 'hard to justify' as unemployment hits 3.7pc, Telstra and Origin profits surge, ASX lower

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Anyone house hunting knows there's been a dearth of properties on the market as sellers have sat on their hands unnerved by rising interest rates. But Domain Boss Jason Pellegrino has told Alicia Barry on The Business, things are picking up as investors bailout of the market and owner occupiers have more confidence interest rates are at or near the peak. Domain Holdings saw a 13 per cent slump in listings in the financial year (worst in Sydney, 21%, and Melbourne, 16%) that led to a 19.3% fall in full year profit to $26.1 million. And The Business is also taking a look at the Australian dollar’s spiral downward and what China and the US have to do with it. The local currency is off another 0.7% today after worse than expected jobs numbers at 63.81US cents. You can catch the program at 8:45pm EST on the ABC News Channel this evening.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The Business tonight with Alicia Barry

children.content: Anyone house hunting knows there's been a dearth of properties on the market as sellers have sat on their hands unnerved by rising interest rates.
But
Domain Boss Jason Pellegrino
has told Alicia Barry on The Business,
things are picking up as investors bailout of the market
and owner occupiers have more confidence interest rates are at or near the peak.
Domain Holdings saw a 13 per cent slump in listings in the financial year (worst in Sydney, 21%, and Melbourne, 16%) that led to a 19.3% fall in full year profit to $26.1 million.
And The Business is also taking a look at
the Australian dollar’s spiral downward
and what China and the US have to do with it.
The local currency is off another 0.7% today after worse than expected jobs numbers at 63.81US cents.
You can catch the program at 8:45pm EST on the ABC News Channel this evening.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As Australia's economy slows down from the Reserve Bank's aggressive interest rate hikes, several major companies have implemented, or warned of, redundancies. But some industries, like hairdressing, are still struggling to find staff. Oh, and it's also getting harder for some people to find their " dream job ." My colleagues Emily Stewart and David Chau have done a great job explaining these dynamics in their summary of today's employment data:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: It's getting harder to find your 'dream job'

featuredLink.title: More Australians out of work, economy sheds 14,600 jobs in July

children.content: As Australia's economy slows down from the Reserve Bank's aggressive interest rate hikes,
several major companies
have implemented, or
warned of, redundancies
But some industries, like hairdressing, are
still struggling to find staff.
Oh, and it's also getting harder for some people to find their "
dream job
My colleagues Emily Stewart and David Chau have done a great job explaining these dynamics in their summary of today's employment data:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Hi there, Emily Stewart jumping in here to update you on what Treasurer Jim Chalmers had to say about Australia's unemployment rate rise. He told reporters in Canberra that the labour market is still incredibly strong despite the modest rise in the jobless rate. "We've anticipated for some time that the unemployment rate would tick up a bit and unfortunately that's what we've seen in these numbers today. "It's still pretty remarkable given everything that's coming at us from around the world that we've got an unemployment rate with a 3 in front of it," he said. Meanwhile Liberal senator Michaelia Cash said the increase means Australians are not getting ahead. "It's incredibly concerning that the economy has actually shed jobs. But more than that, there has been an increase in the number of hours worked. "It is not good news for Australian families," she said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Treasurer Jim Chalmers reacts to jobs figures

children.content: Hi there,
Emily Stewart jumping in here to update you on what Treasurer Jim Chalmers had to say about Australia's unemployment rate rise.
He told reporters in Canberra that the labour market is still incredibly strong despite the modest rise in the jobless rate.
"We've anticipated for some time that the unemployment rate would tick up a bit and unfortunately that's what we've seen in these numbers today.
"It's still pretty remarkable given everything that's coming at us from around the world that we've got an unemployment rate with a 3 in front of it," he said.
Meanwhile Liberal senator Michaelia Cash said the increase means Australians are not getting ahead.
"It's incredibly concerning that the economy has actually shed jobs. But more than that, there has been an increase in the number of hours worked.
"It is not good news for Australian families," she said.

image.altText: Side by side photos of Anthony Albanese and Adam Bandt, both in dark suits, ties and spectacles

items.synopsis: The fate of the government's signature housing policy remains in doubt, with the Greens disappointed by renting measures announced by national cabinet yesterday, but the construction industry has welcomed the move to accelerate the building of 1.2 million new homes.

title.children: Future of Labor's key housing policy uncertain after Greens frustrated with rent measures

image.altText: a group of protesters gather at a stage in high vis

items.synopsis: Thousands of protesters march on Labor's national conference, causing traffic chaos in Queensland's capital.

title.children: Thousands of protesters march on Labor's national conference in Brisbane

image.altText: A male politican in a blue suit and white tie, speaking at a lecturn in front of a sign that reads 'working for Australia'

items.synopsis: A move by the unions to commit Labor to introduce a tax on "super profits" recorded by banks and other corporations has been watered down.

title.children: Union push for 'super profit tax' to fund housing watered down at Labor conference

image.altText: a rocket launches in the outback

items.synopsis: For the first time since NASA shot rockets from Arnhem Land last year, a remote Northern Territory site is looking to fire up again for more launches.

title.children: South Korean company signs 'multi-launch' contract to fire rockets from remote Australia

image.altText: A satellite view of an island in the South China Sea.

items.synopsis: Satellite photos of construction on Triton Island, one of the major islands in the Paracel group that is also claimed by Vietnam and Taiwan, causes speculation a new airstrip is in the works, but analysts say it may be too early to tell.

title.children: 'Everybody take a breath': Questions raised over whether China is building an airstrip on contested island

image.altText: A gas flare

items.synopsis: The WA government removes gas export exemptions for onshore projects, shutting the door on a key pathway in the race to develop valuable reserves near Perth.

title.children: Hard line on WA gas reserves throws spanner in the works of some of Australia's richest people

image.altText: A phone screen showing a mail app with two notifications

items.synopsis: Phishing is the most commonly reported scam in Australia, with scammers harvesting tens of millions of dollars every year from unsuspecting victims.

title.children: It was the most reported scam in Australia last year. Here's how phishing works

image.altText: A close-up of an embryo being surgically prodded

items.synopsis: Affected patients were alerted this week about the contamination at the Royal Prince Alfred Hospital's fertility unit.

title.children: Sydney hospital forced to destroy IVF patients' embryos and shut down fertility laboratory

image.altText: A man with dark hair looks serious as he is photographed outside court.

items.synopsis: Prosecutors will again be able to pursue charges against trucking boss Simiona Tuteru, who was in charge of a driver who fatally crashed into four police officers on Melbourne’s Eastern Freeway.

title.children: Boss of truck driver who killed four police officers in Melbourne freeway crash may face new court action

image.altText: A man wearing a vest that says vision impaired, in the snow with skis

items.synopsis: With a guide following him calling out the turns, Pete Ellson hurtles down the slopes at Falls Creek watched on by everyone on the mountain.

title.children: 'Awe-inspiring' blind 76yo skier takes to the slopes

image.altText: Composite image headshots of Julie Bishop, Mathias Cormann, Anthony Albanese and Katy Gallagher all with WRONG printed undern

items.synopsis: This week marks 10 years of Fact Check at the ABC and the 600 verdicts offer an insight into our political system, writes RMIT ABC Fact Check's Matt Martino.

title.children: After a decade of being fact checked, politicians on both sides have continually repeated this incorrect claim

image.altText: A blurred car driving on the highway with petrol prices showing behind it

items.synopsis: Australians are feeling more pain at the petrol pump as prices rise to the highest level so far this year, and analysts say the rising prices are likely to stay for "the next few weeks" at least.

title.children: Motorists are paying more for petrol now than they have all year — and it's likely to stay that way for weeks

image.altText: A man standing in the middle of a giant museum room with a skylight on the ceiling and artefacts all around the walls

items.synopsis: The museum director said the incident is "highly unusual" and it is working to determine what has been stolen or damaged.

title.children: British Museum fires staff member over missing and stolen items

image.altText: A woman and two children walk down a runway with an small plane behind them.

items.synopsis: It's something we rarely hear about in Australia – for good reason – but there are people living in witness protection programs across the nation.

title.children: New name, new history, new location: Is witness protection really like what we see on TV?

image.altText: A large crowd of people waiting at a train station

items.synopsis: Soccer fans faced long delays getting home after the Matildas' loss to England in the Women's World Cup.

title.children: Two charged over damage to Sydney train infrastructure that caused chaos following Matildas' World Cup loss

image.altText: Indigenous man with grey hair and one eye looks into the distance

items.synopsis: Djiniyini Gondarra, a spiritual leader from north-east Arnhem Land, wants to see his decades-long calls for a treaty fulfilled. But he doesn't believe a Voice will deliver it.

title.children: He's been described as Australia's Gandhi. And this civil rights leader is planning to vote No to a Voice

image.altText: A man with long white hair and white beard, with glasses, smiles at the camera.

items.synopsis: Sunil Badami remembers his uncle wowing the public with 'miracles' like bending spoons with his mind. Decades later, he learnt the devastating secret his uncle hid.

title.children: India's most famous sceptic worked miracles for enraptured audiences. But he carried a secret grief

image.altText: A crowd of hundreds of people with shocked expressions on their faces, some clutching their heads as they lean on a barrier.

items.synopsis: Australians gathered across the country last night for the Matildas' historic semifinal, showing off their green and gold. Here's how it unfolded.

title.children: In pictures: How Australians turned out to support the Matildas' World Cup dream
